description: From Middle English distreynen, from Old French destraindre, from Latin distringō (“to pull asunder”), from dis- (“apart”) + stringō (“to draw tight, strain”).

verbs.description: distrain (third-person singular simple present distrains, present participle distraining, simple past and past participle distrained)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To squeeze, press, embrace; to constrain, oppress.
examples: Thus spake the Prince, and gently 'gan distrain / Now him, now her, between his friendly arms.

entries.meaning: (law, transitive, obsolete) To force (someone) to do something by seizing their property.
examples: to distrain a person by his goods and chattels

entries.meaning: (law, intransitive) To seize somebody's property in place of, or to force, payment of a debt.
